qa_pairs.question: What is Megan Magdangal's teaching experience?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan has been a teacher for six years, working in South San Francisco for one year and in San Francisco for the last five years.
qa_pairs.source_text: my name is Megan I am a teacher of six years I worked in South San Francisco for one year and I spent the last five years teaching in San Francisco

qa_pairs.question: What is Megan's connection to the Bay Area?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan is from the Bay Area, grew up in South San Francisco, her mom still lives there, and she went to college at SF State.
qa_pairs.source_text: Im from the Bay Area um I grew up in South San Francisco my mom still lives there and I went to college in SF state so I stayed pretty local

qa_pairs.question: Why did Megan's family leave San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan's family left San Francisco because the schools weren't good, and her mom was getting picked on by her siblings.
qa_pairs.source_text: they landed up leaving because the schools werent so good my mom was getting picked on from her siblings

qa_pairs.question: How did Megan's mom manage to get a home in South San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan's mom was able to get a home in South San Francisco with the help of her grandparents who gave her a document on a house.
qa_pairs.source_text: my mom when she went through her first marriage she was able to get a home in South San Francisco and back then like you know my grandparents really helped they gave her a document on a house

qa_pairs.question: What challenges did Megan face when looking for housing after college?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan realized she couldn't afford housing unless she shared a house with others, eventually finding a tiny room for $900 in Bayview, which was in a bad area.
qa_pairs.source_text: I started looking for places and I started realizing like I cant afford anything unless I share a house with a bunch of people so I started looking and I had like this price range in my head I was like I want to spend a thousand dollars which wasnt um that not that big of a price range to uh for this area so I uh I found a really tiny room for 900 something um and uh it was in Bayview it was it was in a really bad area

qa_pairs.question: Why did Megan leave her initial living situation in Bayview?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan left because the living situation was chaotic, with the woman in charge letting many people live there, leading to issues like people eating her food.
qa_pairs.source_text: the house the living situation was really crazy this the woman who was in charge of the house she was uh she was just letting all these people live there so I um I decided to leave there because it was just not making sense people were eating my food and it was just drama

qa_pairs.question: What was Megan's experience with teaching in South San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan found it difficult due to low funding, having to teach subjects she wasn't trained for, and the lack of extracurricular activities for students.
qa_pairs.source_text: when I was at the school in South City it was very low funded and I was teaching so many different things and that I wasnt trained for like PE I had to teach music there was no extracurricular for those kids

qa_pairs.question: Why did Megan decide to work at a private school in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan chose to work at a private school because it was a brand new school where she could be a founding teacher, and her previous job was underfunded and chaotic.
qa_pairs.source_text: it was like a brand new school and I was going to be like one of the founding teachers and I just kind of thought that was so cool and um when I was at the school in South City it was very low funded and I was teaching so many different things and that I wasnt trained for

qa_pairs.question: How does the lack of affordable housing affect educators according to Megan?
qa_pairs.answer: The lack of affordable housing makes it difficult for educators to stay near the schools they teach at, adding stress and potentially driving them away from the teaching field.
qa_pairs.source_text: it would be really nice um like its a stressful job and um and to have like that one less you know burden of high rent uh I think it would make a lot of Educators want to stay near the schools they teach at rather than commute far it might also make people want to stay in the teaching field

qa_pairs.question: Why is it important for teachers to have access to housing within the communities they teach?
qa_pairs.answer: Teachers having access to housing within the communities they teach helps them connect better with students and bring community elements into the classroom.
qa_pairs.source_text: because then they get to know the community of the students I think they connect better to their students when theyre a part of the community I think it would help them really like also bring the community into the classroom

qa_pairs.question: What does Megan envision as a nice community?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan envisions a nice community as one with good schools, nice markets, community centers, and support for local businesses.
qa_pairs.source_text: I guess good schools um you know maybe nice markets I guess community centers I I think a lot about kids when I think of a nice community and how to keep them safe and um you know having a good education and stuff like that you know maybe more like Mom and Pop shops like like supporting more local business

qa_pairs.question: What are Megan's views on the current state of San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan feels that San Francisco has become run down, with major corporations taking over and local businesses closing, making it less appealing.
qa_pairs.source_text: I feel like the citys kind of like swaying away from that a lot of places are closing either because theyre getting robbed or because people cant afford them um major corporations you know are kind of taking over there

qa_pairs.question: What solutions does Megan suggest for housing issues in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: Megan suggests making housing affordable for the working class, providing more teacher housing programs, and solving the homeless problem.
qa_pairs.source_text: I think we should try to make it affordable for the working class um it feels like the middle class doesnt really get a lot of opportunity theyre kind of just stuck in this like cycle of just like working in rent teacher housing and um maybe having more programs like that
